questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the casualty after having overdosed on anti-hypertensive medication. On examination, there are multiple cuts on her wrists and history reveals multiple attempts at suicide. On further enquiry, her father reveals she has marked fluctuations in her mood with a history of unstable relationships. Most probable diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
The given history of repetitive self-destructive acts, unstable relationships and mood swings point towards a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder.

Borderline personality disorder:  

  • Classified under Cluster B 
  • Characterized by an unstable affect, mood swings, marked impulsivity, unstable relationships, recurrent suicidal behavior, chronic feelings of emptiness or boredom, identity disturbance, and inappropriate anger.
  • If stressed, may become psychotic.
  • The main defense mechanism is splitting.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with altered bowel habits and intermittent bleeding from the rectum for the past 6 months. Proctoscopy was normal. Colonoscopy was done and the findings as shown in the image below was seen in the entire descending and sigmoid colon. Biopsy revealed tubular adenomatous changes. What is the best method of management in this patient?

choices.text: Total colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis
Total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is diagnostic of Familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome. Since the patient is young, the patient is best treated with total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis. This procedure is usually accompanied by resection of the rectal mucosa.

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):

It is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due to the mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5.

  • Accounts for 1% of all colorectal carcinoma
  • Characterized by the presence of >100 adenomatous polyps in colon and rectum
  • Manifests by late 2nd or early 3rd decade
  • 100% risk of development of cancer
 The current definition of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires evidence of any one of below:
  1. Germline mutation in APC gene
  2. ≥100 colorectal adenomatous polyps (classical definition)
  3. Any colorectal adenomas under age 30 in a patient with a family history of FAP
  4. Intra-abdominal desmoid fibromatosis, osteoma of the mandible, or multiple epidermoid cysts in a patient with a family history of FA

The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA). Following surgery, the patient has to be routinely followed up for ileoanal-pouch surveillance. Upper GI endoscopy should also be performed to evaluate for the presence of duodenal adenomas.

 Variants of FAP are:

  1. Gardner's syndrome- It is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polyps the patients will have
    • Osteomas of the mandible or skull 
    • Epidermal cysts
    • Soft tissue tumors like desmoid tumor
  2. Turcot's syndrome- In addition to the colonic polyps the patients will have central nervous system tumors (primary brain tumors).

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyp usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present in 50% cases.
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma.
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) seen in 75% of cases; it is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma: In the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is ___
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of breathing difficulty and unsuccessful attempts of extubation after total thyroidectomy is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury is often acute. Neuritis or surgical trauma (thyroidectomy) are the most important causes. All the intrinsic muscles are paralyzed in this condition. The vocal cords lie in the median or paramedian position due to the unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles. This leads to dyspnoea and stridor but the voice is good.

Tracheostomy is done as an emergency procedure. Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:

  • Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation) - it involves excising laterally the soft tissue at the junction of membranous cord and vocal process of arytenoid with laser.
  • Partial arytenoidectomy - it involves excision of the medial part of the arytenoid with laser.
  • Reinnervation procedures - these are used to innervate paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.
  • Thyroplasty type II - it creates lateral expansion of larynx.

questions.text: A patient chronically on corticosteroids was diagnosed with a complicated cataract. His slit lamp examination finding is shown below. What is this type of cataract called?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of chronic use of steroids along with slit lamp examination showing a granular appearance in the lens is suggestive of posterior subcapsular cataract.

Posterior subcapsular opacity lies in front of the posterior capsule and has a granular or plaque-like appearance on oblique slit lamp examination .On retro- illumination , black vacuoles are seen which are swollen migratory lens epithelial cells called as Wedl cells (or bladder cells). As it is in the centre of the eye it has a significant impact on vision. Symptoms like glare are often perceived and aggravated by miosis , near visual activity and in bright light. 

The following conditions mainly present with a posterior subcapsular cataract and therefore have a similar clinical picture:

  • Complicated cataract
  • Steroid-induced cataract
  • Radiation

 These cataracts present with central opacities and has difficulty in seeing objects in bright light because:

  • When a person is exposed to bright light, the pupil undergoes miosis (constriction).
  • These central opacities come to lie directly in the path of axial rays, allowing no transmission of rays.
  • Therefore, there is an inability to see objects in bright light.
  • However, in dim light, when there is mydriasis (dilatation of pupil), some rays may pass around the opacity, leading to an improvement in dim-light vision.

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with limping gait and left hip pain. A plain radiograph of his hip shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of limping gait and left hip pain with radiographic findings of the radiolucency and distorted articular surface is suggestive of avascular necrosis. 

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a painful bone condition as a result of diminished blood supply mainly due to trauma or non-traumatic etiologies. 

The typical features are pain with movements in or near the joint, click in the joint, joint stiffness, limping gait, and deformity. Restriction of movements is also a feature of this condition. The radiograph shows reactive new bone formation, increased radiolucency in the subchondral bone, and a distorted articular surface. 

Management in the early stages can involve osteotomy while in late stages pain control, splinting, arthrodesis, and total or partial replacement are preferred.  

Other options: 

Option A: Tuberculosis of the hip is characterized by painful and restricted movements of the hip. The radiographic findings are not appreciable in the early stages. But late stages show periarticular osteoporosis, hazy, and irregular joint margins with a reduction in the joint space, and wandering acetabulum. 

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is usually seen in females in the 4th to 5th decade. Patients present with symmetrical polyarthritis of the proximal finger joints, tenosynovitis, early morning stiffness and pain. RA of the hip can be bilateral. Radiographic findings such as joint space narrowing due to hyaline cartilage destruction, cyst formation, and acetabular protrusion type deformity can be seen.

Option C: Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease of the spine and sacroiliac joint. It typically occurs in the age group 15-25 years with a male preponderance. Features include backache, stiffness, sciatica, and fixed flexion contracture. Radiographic findings show erosion of sacroiliac joints, squaring, and bridging of the vertebral body leading to a bamboo spine appearance.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child presents with intermittent left-sided abdominal pain and recurrent urinary tract infections over the past few months. On examination, mild tenderness over the left costovertebral angle was present. The delayed intravenous urogram of the patient is given below. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
In a child with recurrent urinary tract infection and delayed IVU showing unilateral hydronephrosis, the most likely cause is congenital pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction (PUOJ).

In this child presenting with intermittent left-sided abdominal pain, recurrent urinary tract infections, and mild tenderness over the left costovertebral angle, along with intravenous urogram findings of moderate dilation of the left renal pelvis and calyces, the most common cause is congenital PUJO. PUJO is a congenital condition where there is a narrowing or blockage at the junction where the ureter meets the renal pelvis. This obstruction leads to dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces leading to hydronephrosis on the affected side. 

PUJO can arise due to various factors, including intrinsic obstruction caused by a segment with poor peristalsis due to muscular hypoplasia. Other contributing factors include a higher level of insertion of the ureter into the renal pelvis and the presence of crossing aberrant vessels at the PUJ. These conditions collectively lead to impaired urine flow from the kidney, resulting in hydronephrosis. It is more commonly observed among males and on the left side.

The Anderson–Hynes dismembered pyeloplasty is the preferred surgical management for this condition especially indicated in cases presenting with persistent pain, hypertension, hematuria, secondary renal calculi, and recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Endoscopic management, specifically endopyelotomy, is typically reserved for treating strictures that develop after previous pyeloplasty procedures.

Vesicoureteral reflux (option B) and posterior urethral valve (option C) are associated with hydroureteronephrosis.

Distal ureteric calculus (option A) is associated with proximal ureter dilatation along with hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presented to the psychiatric OPD with low mood, loss of energy,  loss of interest in pleasurable activities, decreased sleep, and appetite for the past 2 months. What is the most appropriate treatment to be started?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette point towards major depressive disorder. SSRIs like fluoxetine are the most appropriate treatment for major depressive disorder. SSRIs should be continued for 6-9 months after complete remission of symptoms in case of a single episode of depression. 

The diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder are as follows:

A. Five or more of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period. At least one of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure.

  • Depressed mood most of the day
  • Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia)
  • Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite
  • Insomnia or hypersomnia
  • Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  • Fatigue or loss of energy
  • Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
  • Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
  • Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

B. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupa­tional, or other important areas of functioning.

C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical condition.

D. The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by schizoaf­fective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

Treatment of depression according to NICE guidelines: 

  • In recent‐onset, mild depression, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is preferred and antidepressants are not recommended.
  • Antidepressants (SSRIs) are recommended for the treatment of moderate to severe depression and for dysthymia along with CBT.
  • For treatment‐resistant depression, recommended strategies include augmentation with lithium or an antipsychotic or the addition of a second antidepressant.
  • The use of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is supported in severe and treatment-resistant depression.

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady presented with painless lumps in the right breast. On examination, two lumps of size 6 x 2 cm and 4 x 1 cm were palpated in the upper outer quadrant. Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes were felt. On evaluation, there was no distant metastasis. What is the TNM staging of this tumor?
questions.solution:
TNM staging of the tumor is T3 N1 M0.

In the given scenario:

  • The bigger lump is 6 cm in size - T3
  • Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes - N1 
  • No distant metastasis - M0. 

In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm). If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump. If lumps are present in bilateral breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.

questions.text: The image shown below shows the technique of insertion of which of the following devices
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the technique of insertion of the laryngeal mask airway.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that is positioned in the hypopharynx.

Supraglottic airway devices are used with both spontaneously and mechanically ventilated patients during anaesthesia.

LMA has the advantages of being used in many settings, including the operating room (alternate route of ventilation), the emergency department (difficult intubation), and out-of-hospital care (paramedics).

This is because it is easy to use, quick to place even for inexperienced providers, and has a very high success rate.

The technique of insertion:

  • The deflated cuff of LMA is lubricated and inserted blindly into the hypopharynx. Once inflated, the cuff forms a low-pressure seal around the entrance to the larynx.
  • Correct placement of the tube is confirmed by giving gentle positive pressure ventilation while checking for chest rise and ETCO2 using capnography.

Other options:

Option A: Oropharyngeal airway is inserted in the patient’s mouth with concavity towards the hard palate. As the airway is inserted it is rotated 180 degrees (concavity towards the tongue) until the flange comes to rest on the patient’s lips. 

Option B: Nasopharyngeal airway is inserted through the nostril (after lubrication) along the natural curvature of the floor of the nasal cavity with the bevel pointing towards the septum. Once the device is inserted the flange should rest on the nostril opening.

Option D: Endotracheal tube is inserted infraglottically after visualizing the vocal cords with direct laryngoscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are incorrectly matched with their imaging modality of choice?

choices.text: Hirschsprung’s disease- Plain x-ray abdomen with air contrast
Neonatal hepatitis- Nuclear medicine; hepatobiliary scintigraphy

questions.solution:
The imaging modality of choice in Hirschsprung's disease is a contrast radiograph with barium or gastrografin enema. 

The most important film is a lateral or oblique view of the rectum during slow filling. It typically shows a low bowel obstruction. The rectum is seen as a narrow tube and a cone-shaped transition zone, seen proximal to the dilated ganglionated bowel. 

 

Other options:

Transfontanel cranial ultrasonography or a neurosonogram reliably delineates ventricular size and anatomy in neonates. It is an excellent primary imaging technique for the evaluation of the many clinical problems related to ventricular dilatation. 

  1. Ventriculomegaly
  2. Differentiating nonobstructive ventricular dilatation from obstructive enlargement (hydrocephalus)
  3. Cause of hydrocephalus
  4. Temporary management of patients with hydrocephalus
  5. Aiding in the management of patients with permanent ventricular shunts

Ultrasound in pyloric stenosis will show a dilated, fluid-filled stomach and proximal duodenum with obstruction. A coexisting volvulus can show as a whirlpool sign. 

Hepatobiliary scintigraphy is a radionuclide imaging that shows metabolic activity in different cell types based on the substance taken up by the various cells.

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in a case of ischemic stroke for all of these conditions, except _________.
questions.solution:
Thrombolysis is contraindicated in recent history of head injury.

Thrombolysis refers to the dissolution of the intravascular clots to prevent ischemic damage and improve blood flow. 

Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (dose 0.9 mg/kg) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. 

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented with abnormal uterine bleeding. The images below shows transverse section of uterus and histology of the specimen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The histopathology specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis is a condition caused by the ingrowth of the endometrial tissue into the uterine wall. The presence of endometrial glands and stroma with the uterine myometrium eventually leads to the thickening of the uterine wall.

Women present with menorrhagia, progressively increasing dysmenorrhea, pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia. Clinical examination revealinf a painful, symmetrical enlargementy of the uterus should suggest adenomyosis. On bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign. 

TVS findings include the salt-and-pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of sub-endometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance (shown in the image below). 

MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

questions.text: Which of the following skeletal muscle relaxants exhibit the following response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine exhibits the above-given response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade.

Train of four protocol is one of the methods used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade. It is done by stimulating the ulnar nerve with a stimulus and watching the contractile responses in the adductor pollicis muscle. Four successive stimuli of 2Hz strength are given at fixed time intervals and the response achieved is plotted as a graph.

Initial stimulus: Amount of Ach released is large enough to compete with the drug at the motor endplate causing maximal contraction of the muscle.

Successive stimuli: Amount of Ach released is insufficient to compete with the drug and results in sequentially diminished contractions

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. Chest X-ray showed the following findings. Which of the following episodes of vomiting corresponds to this illness?

choices.text: Forceful vomiting against a closed glottis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 30-year-old patient presenting with severe upper abdominal pain and vomiting with the inability to pass a nasogastric tube and a chest X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen is suggestive of gastric volvulus. It is associated with severe recurrent retching with the production of minimal vomitus.

Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.

Patients present with the characteristic Borchardt's triad which comprises of:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Chest X-ray shows a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen due to rotation of gastric fundus on the axis of the stomach. Gastric volvulus can be confirmed by a barium study. In barium study, the stomach may be inverted with greater curvature above the lesser curvature, or as the pylorus above the cardia. 

Emergency surgery is indicated for acute volvulus which includes decompression, reduction, and prevention of recurrence. The surgical intervention includes simple gastropexy with diaphragmatic hernia repair. 

Other options:

Option B: Forceful vomiting against a closed glottis is most commonly associated with Boerhaave's syndrome. It results in full-thickness perforation of the lower oesophagus.

Option C: Vomiting of undigested food particles is commonly seen in achalasia cardia which occurs as a result of impaired relaxation of the LES due to loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Patients usually present with the classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss.

Option D: Projectile non-bilious vomitus is seen in congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the bones of the skull. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

All of the above sinuses open into the middle meatus and their ostia lie anterior to the basal lamella of the middle turbinate.

Posterior group: It includes-

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus 
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents to the clinic with a non-specific history of malaise. Mild sensorineural hearing loss had been diagnosed during his early education, although hearing aids were not required. He gives a history of recurrent hematuria and current investigations reveal the same. What is the most likely diagnosis among the following?
questions.solution:
Alport syndrome is the most likely diagnosis. Alport syndrome is a cause of recurrent hematuria, which is associated with sensorineural hearing loss.

A defect in type IV collagen, a major component of the basement membrane, is responsible for Alport syndrome.

Alport syndrome is a genetically heterogeneous disease, 85% is X-linked and the rest may be autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant.

 Other causes of recurrent hematuria

  • Alport syndrome
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
  • Papillary necrosis
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects is seen in an injury to Baum’s loop of the optic radiations?
questions.solution:
Inferior quadrantanopia (pie in the floor) is seen in patients who have an injury to the optic radiations which pass through the parietal lobe. They are also known as Baum’s loop.

Pie in the Sky defects:

  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of inferior fibres of Optic radiations – Meyer’s loop
  • Seen in Temporal lobe lesions

Pie in the Floor defects:

  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of superior fibres of the Optic radiations – Baum’s loop
  • Seen in Parietal lobe lesions

Notable points :

  • Lesion in central chiasma – Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Lesion in anterior chiasma – Junctional scotoma
  • Lesion in optic tract – Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil
  • Radiational lesion and cortical blindness has normal pupillary reaction

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about CT scan?

choices.text: CT consists of unfiltered x-ray beams
It is the investigation of choice for gallstones

questions.solution:
The correct statement is that the CT score of water is 0. 

On CT, each image consists of a matrix of data points (pixels) that are assigned a number that represents the X-ray attenuation(μ) at that point in the body. CT number is a scaled version of μ that is normalised to the X-ray attenuation of water (μW).

CT = 1000 × (μ/μW − 1)

The resulting numbers are called ‘Hounsfield units’(HU). Due to this normalisation, water is assigned 0 HU, and air is assigned a CT number of −1000 HU.

CT numbers:

  • Water = 0 HU
  • Solid soft tissues are centred around 0 HU
  • Lungs = -1000 HU
  • Air = −1000 HU
  • Dense cortical bone = +1000 HU
  • Acute Blood Clot = 60-90 HU
  • Fat = -100 HU

Other options:

Option B: Computed tomography (CT) imaging involves the use of a narrow beam of X-rays that are emitted from a rotating X-ray tube.CT scanners typically use a combination of X-ray beams at different energies and filters to reduce scatter and improve image quality. Therefore, the X-ray beams used in CT imaging are often filtered to enhance image contrast and reduce radiation dose to the patient.

Option C: The investigation of choice for gallstones is an Abdominal ultrasound and not a CT Abdomen. An ultrasound can assess for complications of gallstones, such as inflammation of the gallbladder (cholecystitis) or obstruction of the bile ducts. In cases where ultrasound findings are inconclusive or further characterisation is needed, other imaging modalities such as CT scan or magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) may be used. 

Option D: The mSv (millisievert) value for a non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) scan of the head typically ranges from around 1 to 2 mSv. This radiation dose can vary depending on factors such as the specific CT scanner used, the scanning protocol, and the individual patient characteristics. However, in general, NCCT head scans are associated with relatively low radiation doses compared to other medical imaging procedures.

questions.text: A patient presents with a firm, tender, slow-growing mass below the ear as shown in the image below. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of a parotid abscess. 

A parotid abscess refers to an infection and pus formation in the parotid space. It is caused most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus. Post-surgical cases and debilitated patients with stasis of salivary flow are at risk of developing parotid abscesses.

Patients typically present with unilateral swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present. Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan. Multiple small loculi of pus are seen in the parenchyma. Aspiration of abscess can be done to determine the culture and sensitivity of the infective agent. 

Correction of dehydration, improving oral hygiene, and promoting salivary flow. Intravenous antibiotics are also used in treatment. Surgical drainage of the abscess is done via a preauricular incision.

The parotid gland is enclosed by deep cervical fascia which splits into superficial and deep layers. Parotid space lies deep in the superficial layer. Contents of parotid space include : 

  • parotid gland 
  • lymph nodes associated with parotid gland
  • facial nerve 
  • external carotid artery
  • retromandibular vein

Other options: 

Option A: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis and is formed when pus breaks inferiorly, through the tip of the mastoid and collects in the upper part of the neck. The onset is sudden with pain, fever, tender neck swelling, and torticollis. There will be a history of purulent otorrhea.

Option C: Osteoma of the mandible is usually slow growing and asymptomatic. It usually occurs in the mandibular condyle area. They are usually detected incidentally during a radiographic examination.

Option D: Upper cervical lymphadenopathy occurs in the neck region following infection in the area drained by these structures.

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in________.
questions.solution:
The Gartner's duct is a remnant of the Wolffian ducts in women. These are located in the broad ligament and the vagina.

The remnants of Wolffian ducts (Gartner's duct) in females are located in the broad ligament and vagina. It is an imperfect duct that runs below and parallel to the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus until the internal os, after which it passes into the cervix. It then runs forwards, reaching the anterolateral part of the vaginal wall.

Gartner's duct cysts are located in the vagina or broad ligament. They are usually asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during a routine examination. Symptoms if present, might include dyspareunia, pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination reveals a tense cyst, seen bulging from beneath the vaginal wall.

Differentials include epidermoid cysts, Bartholin's gland cyst, uterine prolapse, cystocele, rectocele, urethral diverticula.

Treatment is observation in most cases. Marsupialization or excision may be done if large and symptomatic.

questions.text: An incidental ovarian mass is found when evaluating a 19-year-old girl for kidney stones. The mass is removed and its contents are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with an asymptomatic ovarian mass consisting hair, bone, and sebaceous material is a mature teratoma. 

Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. There are three classes of teratomas:

  • Mature (benign) teratomas (eg: Dermoid cyst)
  • Immature (essentially malignant) teratomas (eg: solid teratoma)
  • Monodermal (highly specialized) tumors (eg: Struma ovarii)

Mature cystic teratoma, also known as dermoid cysts are unilocular in structure and have a smooth surface. They usually are lined by squamous epithelium with hair follicles leading to the formation of sebaceous material and hair. Other structures like teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and mucous membranes can also be found. 

Most patients are asymptomatic. Some patients may have symptoms because of the mass size of the teratoma. In other patients, ovarian teratomas can result in torsion of the ovary. Other rare complications include rupture of the cyst and spillage of contents into the abdominal cavity. 

Treatment of mature teratomas involves excision in order to prevent complications. Otherwise, mature teratomas are generally innocent. 

Other options: 

Option A - Immature teratomas such as solid teratomas of the ovary are solid and trabeculated. They also contain cartilage, bone, hair, and sebaceous material. There is no structural order. They are generally malignant. Grossly, they have a smooth external surface and are solid on sectioning. There may be areas of necrosis or hemorrhage. 

The following image shows both mature (left) and immature teratomas (right). 

Option C - Struma ovarii is a type of highly specialized teratoma that contains only thyroid tissue. If it is functioning, it may lead to hyperthyroidism. 

Option D - Granulosa cell tumors arise from the sex cords of the gonads. They are solid and generally produce estrogen. They can cause precocious puberty in children, hyperestrogenism in adults, and post-menopausal bleeding. They vary in appearance and range from microscopic to large, solid and cystic, encapsulated masses. If hormonally active, they may be yellow due to intracellular lipids.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

The synechiae are caused by the following factors:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum haemorrhage or abortion
  • Tubercular endometritis
  • Uterine infections with or without intra-uterine device

Asherman syndrome:

It refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients may have amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss because of inadequate placentation.

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: Which among the following is called malignant  glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Ciliary block glaucoma is also called as malignant glaucoma/inverse glaucoma.

It can be seen after any intraocular surgery. Forward flow of the aqueous is blocked as tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against lens/ intraocular lens (IOL)/anterior hyaloid of vitreous. Hence, aqueous starts collecting in the vitreous cavity. 

Clinical features :

  • Persistent flat AC
  • Negative Seidel’s test
  • Raised intraocular pressure (IOP)

Treatment

  • Atropine (malignant glaucoma also called inverse glaucoma since atropine is used), timolol, acetazolamide
  • Nd:Yag laser hyaloidotomy: making an opening in the anterior hyaloid membrane
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text: A housewife presents with complaints of a blocked nose, loss of smell, and dry, greenish crusty nasal discharge. On examination, nasal cavities appear roomy and turbinates are atrophied. Which of the following surgeries can be done on this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis. Young’s and modified Young’s operations are done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.

In Young’s operation, both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps. They are opened after 6 months or later when the mucosa may revert back to normal and crusting will be reduced.

Modified Young’s operation aims at partially closing the nostrils.

Other options:

Options A and C: Submucous resection and septoplasty are done for deviated nasal septum.

Option D: Vidian neurectomy is done for vasomotor rhinitis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The finding of dactylitis along with the shrunken spleen is suggestive of sickle cell disease.

In sickle cell disease, repeated splenic micro-infarcts cause loss of splenic function and shrinkage. Vaso-occlusion causes hand-foot syndrome with painful infarction of the digits and dactylitis.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the point mutation in the β-globin gene, which results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

Factors that predispose to sickling are infection, dehydration, and acidosis.

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated.

Clinical features:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice
  • Painful bone crisis - hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome - Typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • The aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    •         Adolescence or early adulthood- autosplenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenzae septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features- priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled red cells on the peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2 and HbF and S spike. The changes in the skull resemble a crewcut in radiographic studies as a result of compensatory erythroid hyperplasia.

Other manifestations include:

  • Acute splenic sequestration due to venous obstruction, needing emergency transfusion/splenectomy
  • Painful ischemic crises due to vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal tissue
  • Renal papillary necrosis leading to isosthenuria
  • Cerebrovascular strokes
  • Chronic lower leg ulcers
  • Priapism in males

questions.text: The most common complication of pathological myopia is_____.
questions.solution:
Macular degeneration is the most common complication of myopia, followed by rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Complications of pathological myopia include the following:

  • Macular degeneration
  • Retinal detachment
  • Complicated cataract
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Choroidal hemorrhage
  • Strabismus fixus convergence
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma, which is not a complication, but reported to occur in association with pathological myopia

questions.text: A boxer is wheeled into the ER with complaints of double vision after suffering a severe blow to his face during a match. On examination, there is a flattening of malar prominence, trismus and a step deformity of the infraorbital margin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of diplopia, flat malar prominence, trismus, and step deformity in the infraorbital margin is suggestive of fracture of zygoma or tripod fracture.

Zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone in the face. The zygoma fracture is separated at its three processes - the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital margin, and the zygomaticotemporal suture. It has the following clinical features:

  • Flattening of malar prominence. 
  • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process. 
  • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve. 
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin.
  • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament. 
  • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia. 
  • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with fever, cough, dyspnea, arthralgia, and a painful rash on the lower limbs suggestive of erythema nodosum. A chest X-ray was taken and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggests the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum (as shown below), uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, exertional breathlessness, and radiographic infiltrates.

 

Investigation findings in sarcoidosis are as follows:

  • Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests 
  • Hypercalcemia (due to increased synthesis of calcitriol [1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D] by alveolar macrophages) and hypercalciuria (can lead to nephrocalcinosis)
  • Pulmonary function test - the most common abnormality is an isolated decrease in diffusion of carbon monoxide (DLCO). A restrictive pattern is seen in patients with more advanced pulmonary disease. Approximately 15-20% of patients have an obstructive pattern
  • Bronchoscopy shows a typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage
  • Chest X-ray is useful for staging sarcoidosis
  • HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities that follow a perilymphatic distribution centered on broncho-vascular bundles and the subpleural areas

The presence of erythema nodosum with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray is sufficient to make the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. A tissue biopsy is not required in this case. A typical presentation with classical HRCT features may also indicate the diagnosis. In all other cases, the diagnosis should be confirmed by histological examination of the involved organ.

A chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy in sarcoidosis is shown below,

Management of sarcoidosis is as follows:

  • Asymptomatic patients- monitored for disease progression
  • Localized/ limited cutaneous and ocular lesions- treated using topical steroids
  • Multisystem involvement:
    • Systemic steroids
    • Other drugs like hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and infliximab are considered when the steroids are ineffective or not tolerated

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Fluent aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.

Lesions in the categorical hemisphere lead to

  1. Broca's aphasia is caused due to an injury in the inferior frontal gyrus. It causes nonfluent aphasia. Affected individuals have slow speech and difficulty in generating verbal or written words.
  2. Wernicke's aphasia is caused due to a lesion in the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus. It produces a type of fluent aphasia in which speech itself is normal but it is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense. The patient also fails to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words, so other aspects of the use of language are compromised.
  3. Anomic aphasia- When a lesion damages the angular gyrus in the categorical hemisphere without affecting Wernicke or Broca areas, there is no difficulty with speech or the understanding of auditory information. But there is trouble understanding written language or pictures because visual information is not processed and transmitted to the Wernicke area.
  4. Global aphasia- In this, both understanding and speaking is impaired. It is also non-fluent aphasia.
  5. Acalculia- Impairment of mathematical ability. Occurs due to an impairment to the left frontal lobe.

Option B: Broca's or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Option C: Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia. This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Option D: Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

questions.text: What kind of suturing is depicted below?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts subcuticular sutures.

The subcuticular suture technique is performed by taking a bite alternatively on either side of the wound and gently pulling simultaneously until the end. This is used in the skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily.

Either absorbable or non-absorbable suture material may be used.

There are four frequently used suture techniques.

Interrupted:  the needle should be inserted at right angles to the incision and then passed through both aspects of the suture line and exit again at the right angle.

The distance from the entry point of the needle to the edge of the wound (x) should be approximately the same as the depth of the tissue (x) being sutured, and each successive suture should be placed at twice this distance apart (2x).

 

Continuous: The first suture is placed in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner till the far end of the wound.

 

Mattress: Mattress sutures may be either vertical or horizontal and are used for the eversion or inversion of a wound edge.

The initial suture is inserted like in an interrupted suture, but then the needle is moved either horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound.

questions.text: A young woman presents with skin rashes shown in the image below. She also complains of  easy bruisability and bleeding from gums. Her CBC report revealed platelet count 15,000/µL, normal RBC and WBC counts. Her peripheral smear was normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is immune thrombocytopenic purpura.

The given image showing petechiae and the clinical scenario are suggestive of a bleeding disorder. CBC shows isolated thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear does not reveal any hemolysis. Hence, the other conditions are ruled out. 

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder with autoantibodies against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It can either be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE or infections like HIV and hepatitis C.

It presents with features of mucocutaneous bleeding. CBC shows isolated thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear does not reveal any hemolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an early complication of fracture?
questions.solution:
Complex regional pain syndrome -CRPS(earlier known as Reflex sympathetic dystrophy or Sudeck's dystrophy or algodystrophy) is a late complication of fracture. Rest options are early complications

CRPS is divided into 2 types. CRPS type 1 occurs after trivial trauma or fracture and is explained below.

It occurs as a sequela of trauma and presents as a swollen, tender, and painful condition. It progressively undergoes atrophy of skin, muscle, and even nail over weeks resulting in fixed deformity at last. X-rays classically show spotty or patchy rarefaction. Earlier recognition and treatment initiation makes the prognosis relatively better.  Long term physiotherapy together with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs form the mainstay of treatment. Ganglion blockers in resistant cases can improve the condition.

CRPS type 2 is related to causalgia after nerve injury.

Other options:

Fat embolism syndrome-Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of the long bone or other major trauma.The classical clinical triad consists of respiratory distress,neurological abnormalities and petechial haemorrhages.

 

Related Pearl: Acute compartment and Crush syndrome

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes < 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Which among the following IV anaesthetics does not cause myocardial depression?
questions.solution:
Etomidate, a short-acting I.V. anesthetic agent doesn’t cause myocardial depression.

Etomidate is the most cardiac stable intravenous agent due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptor. Hence, etomidate is the I.V. agent of choice in patients with coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, and cerebral vascular disease.

Side effects of Etomidate:

  • The highest incidence of nausea and vomiting among inducing agents
  • Superficial thrombophlebitis and pain on injection
  • Adrenocortical suppression

Note: Although Ketamine has an indirect sympathetic stimulatory effect, it possesses a direct negative inotropic effect on the myocardium. Hence, ketamine has to be used cautiously in critically ill patients with shock, as they are prone to have a depletion of endogenous catecholamines. Ketamine infusion in such patients can unmask its direct negative inotropic effects and further decrease the blood pressure and cardiac output.

Hence, for this MCQ, Etomidate is the best answer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with amenorrhea, headache,  vomiting, loss of libido, and galactorrhea from 3 months. On examination, her vitals are within range but her eye examination shows bitemporal hemianopia. Which of the following drug is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of prolactinoma of the pituitary. Among the given options, cabergoline is the preferred drug for this patient.

Prolactinoma: Prolactin-secreting lactotroph adenomas are the most frequent type of hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas. The symptoms include

  • Headache and vomiting
  • Bitemporal hemianopia suggestive of a local mass effect
  • Increased intracranial pressure due to a pituitary tumor
  • In females- amenorrhea, galactorrhea, loss of libido, and infertility
  • In males- impotence, loss of libido, and gynecomastia

The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

Treatment is only required in symptomatic cases as microadenomas rarely progress to macroadenomas. The mainstay of treatment is medical management. Dopamine and dopamine agonists are used and they act as inhibitory signals to prolactin secretion in the pituitary. 

Cabergoline is a long-acting dopamine receptor agonist with high D2 receptor affinity and is the preferred drug for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia because of its greater efficacy and lower side effects. It effectively suppresses prolactin secretion for >14 days after a single oral dose. At higher doses, it is used in some patients with acromegaly, alone or along with somatostatin analogs.

Another drug used in prolactinoma is bromocriptine. It is shorter-acting when compared with cabergoline. The adverse effects of bromocriptine include hypotension and nausea.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the surgery out-patient with a left-sided breast lump which she noticed on self breast examination  3weeks ago. She has no other complaints. On palpation, the lump seems to be mobile and firm. Mammogram revealed a benign lesion. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on the clinical scenario is fibroadenoma and the best next step in the management of Fibroadenoma is to Reassure the patient and do regular follow-up.

Fibroadenoma is one of the aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI). The most common age group affected is 15-25 years (early reproductive period) with a peak incidence in the second decade.

It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. Popcorn calcification is seen in mammography.

Option A : Biopsy is not required for Fibroadenoma unless there is a suspicion of Malignancy but based on the clinical and imaging findings the given lesion is benign.

Option C:Excision is not advised unless there is suspicious histology on fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC). Giant fibroadenomas are >5 cm in size, common in adolescent girls, and require excision by submammary incision.

Option D: Tamoxifen is a SERM-Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator used in the management of ER positive Breast carcinoma.

questions.text: A 52-year-old​ postmenopausal woman, with DUB, has an endometrial thickness of 7 mm on ultrasound. Next line of management is?
questions.solution:
For a postmenopausal woman, with DUB, with an endometrial thickness of 7 mm on ultrasound, the next line of management is endometrial biopsy.

In a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness (In a perimenopausal woman, it should not exceed 10 mm). If it exceeds 4 mm in a postmenopausal woman, then histopathological examination (HPE) of the endometrium is mandatory, irrespective of the presence or absence of symptoms.

Hysteroscopy and biopsy is a better method for HPE than other blind curettage methods, a biopsy is made from suspicious areas after visualization, and chances of missing the lesion are less.

questions.text: Neologism is a disorder of:
questions.solution:
Neologism is a disorder of the form of thought. Neologism refers to making new words that do not exist and using them meaninglessly, usually seen in schizophrenia.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT
 

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."
 

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"
 
 

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT

(A) Obsession and compulsion

(i) Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

(ii) Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them
(B) Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud"
 

DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Derealization

Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal

  • "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

(vi) Depersonalization

Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body

  • "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

(vii) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)

 

DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of nasogastric tube insertion in the correct order.
  1. Inject 10 mL of air through the tube while auscultating the left upper quadrant of the abdomen.
  2. Gently insert the nasogastric tube into the nostril, at 90 degree angle to the long axis of the head.
  3. Ask the patient to sit upright and flex the neck forward.
  4. Ask the patient to take small sips of water and swallow.
  5. Tape the tube in place.
questions.solution:
The correct order of steps in the process of insertion of a nasogastric (NG) tube is:

  1. Lubricate the first 2 to 3 inches of the tube with lignocaine jelly lubricant.
  2. Have the patient flex the neck forward, bringing his/her chin towards the chest.
  3. Slowly and gently begin inserting the tube into the nostril straight back at a 90-degree angle to the long axis of the head.
  4. Have the patient begin taking small sips of water through a straw and swallow as you gently advance the tube. Timing the advancement of the tube in conjunction with the patient swallowing greatly facilitates the passage of the NG tube into the stomach. 
  5. Check the position of the tube by:
    • Injecting 10 mL air through the tube and listening to the left upper quadrant for a rush of the air.
    • Obtaining radiographs: radiography is the gold standard for determining the correct placement of NG tubes.
  6. Tape the tube in place. 

Indications for NG tube include:

  • Gastrointestinal lavage or aspiration in patients with suspected or known overdose
  • Gastric decompression in cases of gastric outlet obstruction, intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in acid-induced diarrhoea that is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions
  • Nutritional support and administration of medications via GI route

Contraindications for NG tube include:

  • Significant facial trauma or basilar skull fracture
  • Esophageal burns or caustic ingestion
  • Recent surgery on esophagus or stomach
  • Esophageal stricture or atresia

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of frequent episodes of dysphagia and postprandial chest pain. Her barium study is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of dysphagia and postprandial chest pain with a barium study showing a protrusion of a portion of the stomach through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm is suggestive of a hiatus hernia.

Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.

Types of hiatus hernia:

Type 1 or sliding hernia - gastroesophageal junction migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD.

Type 2 or rolling hiatus hernia - gastroesophageal junction is normal in position but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia. Clinical features include dysphagia and chest pain. In severe cases, it can cause obstruction, strangulation, ischemia, perforation, and compression of the lungs, leading to impaired lung function.

Type 3 or mixed hiatus hernia - a combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia.

Type 4 hiatus hernia - other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Ex:- Colon.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation methods is not used to diagnose CSF rhinorrhea?
questions.solution:
Nasal endoscopy is not used to diagnose CSF rhinorrhea.

 

CSF rhinorrhea refers to the leakage of clear or blood-tinged CSF into the nose. Fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause of this. Other causes include accidental or surgical trauma, infection and inflammation of the sinuses, neoplasms, and congenital lesions associated with skull base defects or may occur spontaneously.

Diagnosis:

  • High-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak in this condition.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - when cerebrospinal fluid mixed with blood is collected on a piece of filter paper, it will show a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

Treatment:

  • Early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea are managed conservatively by placing the patient in a semi-sitting position. Blowing of the nose, sneezing, and straining should be avoided. 
  • Prophylactic antibiotics can be administered to prevent meningitis.
  • Persistent cases may be treated surgically by the intracranial or nasal endoscopic approach.
  • The nasal endoscopic approach is useful for leaks from the frontal sinus, cribriform plate, and ethmoid or sphenoid sinuses.

Other options:

Option A: Skull X ray can be done to diagnose the type of skull fracture, which is the cause of CSF rhinorrhea.

However, it cannot be used to localize the site of the leak.

Option D: CT cisternogram is done in cases where beta-2 transferrin detection is not available. It involves an intrathecal injection of iohexol followed by a CT scan. It is not preferred nowadays.

questions.text: A  30-year-old male is posted for revision laparotomy surgery. He gives a history of jaundice following the previous surgery. Which drug should likely be avoided?
questions.solution:
Halothane must not be given to patients with unexplained liver dysfunction following previous anesthetic exposure. This is because halothane-induced hepatitis is immune-mediated due to antibodies against highly reactive trifluoroacetyl chloride which is a metabolite of halothane.

Halothane hepatitis is rare with an incidence of 1 per 35,000 cases but very fatal, with a mortality of 50-75%.

Risk factors for halothane hepatitis:

  • Multiple exposures to halothane at short intervals
  • Middle-aged obese women – because halothane undergo extensive metabolism in obese patients
  • Familial predisposition to halothane

The liver in halothane hepatitis shows centrilobular necrosis.

questions.text: What is the cause of lactational amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
The cause of lactational amenorrhea is increased prolactin secretion as a result of the baby sucking at the mother's breast.

Lactational amenorrhea:

  • It is a type of secondary amenorrhea due to the effect of prolactin secretion.
  • During lactation, there are pulsatile bursts of prolactin secretion in response to suckling.
  • Prolactin suppresses GnRH, LH, and FSH, causing lactational amenorrhea.
  • Regular lactation with one feed at night delays ovulation and pregnancy for up to 6 months, provided the woman remains amenorrhic.
  • After 6 months, lactation has no bearing on ovulation and pregnancy can occur despite amenorrhea; therefore, other forms of contraception may be needed.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) depicts neovascularization, which is the hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The neovascularization arises from the optic nerve head; there is neovascularization of the disc (NVD) along the large vessels and neovascularization elsewhere (NVE).

The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative factors.

Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Background Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and Blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • NeoVascularization of the optic Disc (NVD)
  • NeoVascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of the fundus (NVE)

Advanced Diabetic Eye Disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

Diabetic Maculopathy is a separate entity that is applied to the changes that occur in the macula such as macular edema or ischemia.

Cotton wool spots (old name soft exudates) appear as whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins. These represent areas of nerve fiber infarcts. Common causes are hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

questions.text: A primigravida at 12 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of the expulsion of grape-like vesicles per vaginum for 1 day. She was diagnosed as a case of molar pregnancy on USG.  In addition, she has an adnexal lesion as given below.  What is the likely finding____
questions.solution:
The given USG image shows theca lutein cysts in the ovary. The ovaries contain multiple theca-lutein cysts in 25 to 60 percent of women with a complete mole.

They are usually bilateral and are also seen in multiple pregnancy. These likely result from the overstimulation of lutein elements by massive amounts of hCG. The contained fluid is rich in chorionic gonadotropin. It also contains estrogen and progesterone.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the hospital with complaints of swelling in the neck as given in the image. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is a congenital sequestration of lymphatic channel
Sclerotherapy is not used in treatment

questions.solution:
The given image depicts a lymphangioma, also known as cystic hygroma. They are brilliantly transilluminant.

Lymphangiomas are congenital benign tumors of the lymphatic system. They are the isolated cystic mass of lymphatic tissue that has the ability to produce lymph. Over time the tumor enlarges due to the accumulation of lymph within the cyst.

Types of lymphangiomas: 

  • Simple or capillary lymphangioma: They occur subcutaneously in the head, neck, and axilla. They may also occur within the internal organs and connective tissues in the thoracic and abdominal cavities.
  • Cavernous lymphangioma or cystic hygroma: They also occur in the neck or axilla. Rarely they may occur in retroperitoneum.

Treatment includes surgical excision of the tumor and image-guided sclerotherapy.

If there is any residual lymphatic malformation after the treatment, then a conservative excision or unroofing of the cyst is done. It may be combined with sclerosing therapy or repeated partial excisions.

Note: The terms lymphangioma and cystic hygromas are older terms. They are now called lymphatic malformations.
