questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to the refraction room. You read his previous prescription which mentions blurred vision and eye strain due to astigmatism. What is the type of astigmatism, if the horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian?
questions.solution:
The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian in Against-the-rule astigmatism.

Other options:

With the rule, astigmatism: The vertical meridian is rendered more curved due to the pressure of the eyelids. It is normally seen in the eyes.

Oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not the horizontal and vertical meridians although they are at right angles to each other.

Bi-oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other; for example, one may be at 40 degrees and the other, at 100 degrees.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of peptic ulcer disease came with features suggestive of peritonitis and underwent emergency laparotomy. The wound is closed by the following technique. What is true regarding the technique shown?

choices.text: It provides positive pressure to the wound
Continuous pressure leads to faster wound healing
Reduces the need of skin grafting procedures
Air gaps should be present for wound culture sampling

questions.solution:
The technique used to close the wound is negative pressure dressing/therapy otherwise also called vacuum assisted closure. The true statement regarding the technique is that they reduce the need of skin grafting procedures.(Option C)

Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) is a method of wound management, which uses negative pressure(Option A) for spontaneous healing or by lesser reconstructive options. Negative pressure therapy stabilizes the wound environment by reducing wound edema and bacterial load,as well as improves tissue perfusion by angiogenesis and thereby stimulating granulation tissue formation. All this improves the possibility of primary closure of wounds and reduces the need for plastic procedures.

Method of VAC application includes thorough debridement, adequate haemostasis and application of sterile foams dressing. A fenestrated tube is embedded in the foam and the wound is sealed with adhesive tape to make it airtight. The fenestrated tube is connected to a vacuum pump with a fluid collection container. The ideal pressure applied is 125 mm Hg. 

VAC therapy is simpler and more effective than conventional dressings for the management of difficult wounds in terms of reduction in wound volume, depth, treatment duration and cost effective.

Indications of VAC therapy includes diabetic foot ulcers, bed sores,burn injuries,crush injuries, sternal/abdominal wound dehiscence, fasciotomy wounds and animal bites/frostbite wounds.

VAC therapy is contraindicated in patients with malignant wounds such as Marjolin’s ulcer,untreated osteomyelitis, presence of fistulae or necrotic tissue underneath the dressing.

Other options - 

Option B - Intermittent pressure application is more effective than continuous pressure for faster wound healing as it generates more blood flow during vacuum “off” phase as well as increases granulation tissue formation almost twice faster than continuous pressure.

Option D - Air leak in the dressing should be avoided as it leads to continual flow of air over the wound surface leading to desiccation of tissue and eschar formation. This eschar seals the wound with retained exudate and leads to worsening of the wound.The pressure in VAC dressing gradually reduces over 48 hours therefore, dressings should be changed on the 3rd day. Wound culture samples can be taken when changing VAC dressings.

questions.text: A 2-year-old was brought to the emergency department with difficulty swallowing for the last few hours. The X-ray is given below. Which is the next best step to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of the child presenting with difficulty in swallowing and the given x-rays are suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin/disc battery.

The given x-rays are anteroposterior and lateral views of the chest and neck. Coins, disk batteries, and small toy items are commonly ingested by children. 

The flat surface of a coin in the esophagus is seen on the anteroposterior view (AP view) i.e; they are oriented in the coronal plane. The edge is seen on the lateral view. Coins lying in the esophagus tend to lie in the coronal plane, whereas coins lying in the trachea lie in the sagittal plane.

Presenting symptoms are choking, gagging, and coughing followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat. Respiratory distress is seen if the esophageal foreign body impinges on the larynx or tracheal wall.

Imaging with PA and lateral views of the chest and abdomen should be done. 

Treatment includes the removal of the foreign body by esophagoscopy.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with difficulty breathing. It is noted that his symptoms improve when he cries. In which disease does the symptom improve upon crying?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario stridor in an infant that relieves on crying is suggestive of choanal atresia.

Improvement of stridor on crying is seen in gross obstruction like choanal atresia while laryngomalacia presents with worsening of stridor while crying or feeding. Sinusitis presents with stretor rather than stridor and it does not relieve while crying.

Choanal atresia is the persistence of the bucconasal membrane, unilateral is more common and may remain undiagnosed until adult life, bilateral atresia will present as a respiratory obstruction in the newborn. The initial clinical evaluation consists of placing a large laryngeal mirror under each nostril and checking for fogging, this is known as the laryngeal mirror test.

Diagnosis can be made by:

  • Presence of mucoid discharge in the nose
  • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
  • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx
  • Putting methylene blue dye into the nose and checking its passage to the pharynx
  • Putting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph
  • CT in the axial plane 

Management: In bilateral atresia, emergency treatment is to provide an airway, which is done by McGovern's technique- (a feeding tube with a large hole that provides a good oral airway), this removes the need for tracheostomy. Definitive treatment is correcting the atresia either by trans palatal or transnasal approach, which is usually done at one and a half years of age.

  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • 30% of cases are bony and 70% are mixed
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome

    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.
  • CT scan is the best investigation

  • Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases.

questions.text: What is the sequence of pubertal changes in girls?
questions.solution:
The sequence of pubertal changes seen in girls is thelarche → pubarche → menarche.

Puberty marks the normal physiologic transition from childhood to sexual and reproductive maturity. The order of changes in puberty are: 

  1. Thelarche - It refers to breast budding, and is the first visible sign. It indicates the competency of the hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis. It appears between the age of 9-11 years, and is described using Tanner staging.
  2. Adrenarche - It refers to the generation of androgens (estrogen and testosterone) from the adrenal gland. 
  3. Pubarche - It refers to the development of pubic hair, and occurs usually 6 months after thelarche. It is also described using Tanner staging.
  4. Menarche - It refers to the first occurrence of menstruation. 

Following breast and pubic hair growth, adolescents undergo an accelerated increase in height. This is known as growth spurt and occurs between ages 10.5 to 13.5 years.

questions.text: A patient is asked to keep subtracting 7 from 100. This test is for examining?
questions.solution:

Memory:

Memory is of 3 types:

  • Immediate memory and recall are usually tested by digit span/ digit repetition test.
    • Digit span test: Digits spelled at the rate of 1 digit per second. It is of two types: Digit forward and Digit backward.
    • Digit forward: Reproduction of increasingly longer digits. E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –9.
    • Digit backward: Reproduction of longer digits in the backward direction. Eg: Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat it backward. 9 -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2.

  • Recent memory: Ask them how they reached the hospital or what they ate for breakfast.
  • Remote memory: Relevant questions from the past like close relative's birth dates.

  • Digit span test.

Its etiology is unknown, but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and inherited tendency and certain areas of the body (triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip).

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision of the keloid scar has a high rate of recurrence.

questions.text: Feeding is done through the given method. Which of the following is not a complication of this?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a central line. Pneumothorax, osteoporosis, and refeeding syndrome are likely complications in patients receiving total parenteral nutrition through a central line. Aspiration pneumonia is more common in enteral feeding and can be prevented by placing the patient in a semi-recumbent position while feeding.

Complications of enteral nutrition are as follows: 

  1. Tube-related (most common): Malposition, displacement, blockage, breakage/leakage, local complications (e.g. erosion of skin/mucosa)
  2. Gastrointestinal: Diarrhoea, bloating, nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, aspiration, constipation
  3. Metabolic/biochemical: Electrolyte disorders, vitamin, mineral, and trace element deficiencies, drug interactions
  4. Infective: Exogenous (handling contamination) and endogenous (patient)

Other options:

Option A: Refeeding syndrome is a significant metabolic complication of both parenteral and enteral feeding. It occurs days after feeding is commenced in patients who have been severely malnourished. The major pathological process is hypophosphatemia which causes fluid and electrolyte shifts between the intra- and extracellular compartments.

Option B: Osteoporosis and osteomalacia are complications of long-term parenteral nutrition and may lead to fractures or kidney stones. Calcium, phosphate, vitamin D supplementation, and bisphosphonates can help prevent as well as treat this complication.

Option C: Pneumothorax is the most common complication of line insertion and most commonly occurs during the insertion of subclavian lines. It is managed by insertion of a chest drain.

questions.text: A 50 year old female was brought to the hospital with a history of severe pain in the left renal angle for the past 7 hours. Abdominal X ray was performed and the image (zoomed to the left)  is given below. What is the treatment of choice in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Abodminal X Ray shows a Staghorn calculi. The treatment of choice for Staghorn calculi is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

PCNL is the treatment of choice for Staghorn calculi. PCNL is indicated in the following types of renal calculi:

  • Large renal stones of diameter more than 2cm
  • Staghorn calculi
  • Multiple stones
  • Proximal ureteral stone: >1 cm

Technique: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique and stones are removed.

Option A: Extracorporeal shock-wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is effective for the treatment of stones having diameters of up to 1.5 cm. In ESWL, crystalline stones disintegrate under the impact of shock waves produced by the ESWL machine.

Option C: Ureteroscopical removal - Stones are retrieved by either using wire retrieval baskets (if <6 mm and in the distal ureter)

Option D: Open surgery is obsolete nowadays. Subcapsular Nephrectomy is done for longstanding obstructing calculus that can result in chronic inflammatory change in the kidney with substantial if not complete loss of function leading to Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP).

questions.text: As an intern, you are assessing a 35-year-old woman who was admitted to the emergency department with multiple rib fractures after a road traffic accident. During the examination, you notice paradoxical chest movement, leading to a diagnosis of respiratory failure. Her chest X-ray is shown below. You will manage the patient using all the following methods except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the X-ray displaying contiguous rib fractures on the right side indicate flail chest, chest strapping or splinting should be avoided in management of flial chest.

Flail Chest :

  • A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage.
  • This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures, i.e. 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places.
  • The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an underlying pulmonary contusion as well.
  • On inspiration the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards and less air therefore moves into the lungs and on expiration, the segment moves outwards, it is called as paradoxical respiration.

Diagnosis is made clinically, not by radiography. To confirm the diagnosis the chest wall can be observed for paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment for several respiratory cycles and during coughing. Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement and the associated lung contusion are all causes of the hypoxia and respiratory failure. The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

Treatment :

  • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided
  • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration (Option b ), adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia and physiotherapy (Option d ).
  • IPPV (Intermitent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for cases developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen (Option a ).

questions.text: What is the recommended margin for local excision in a patient with malignant melanoma invading up to a depth of 0.08 mm?
questions.solution:
The recommended margin for local excision in a patient with malignant melanoma invading up to a depth of 0.08 mm is 1 cm.

Melanoma is a cancer of melanocytes and can therefore arise in skin, mucosa and retina. Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common type and arises in a pre-existing naevus. Other forms include nodular melanoma, lentigo maligna, and acral lentiginous.

  • Change in size, shape, colour and thickness (elevation/nodularity or ulceration)

questions.text: A nulliparous lady, with a BMI of 23, presents with hirsutism. Ultrasonography was done, and the obtained image is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery. The patient's clinical history and given USG image are indicative of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 μg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only in the case of

  • Failure of medical therapy
  • Hyperstimulation
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component. By convention, the latter denotes the direction of nystagmus. questions.text: What is the chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole?
questions.solution:
Partial hydatidiform mole has 69XXY or 69XXX karyotype.

Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

Partial moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg with two sperms.
  • The karyotype is usually triploid (69, XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92, XXXY).
  • Fetal tissues are typically present.
  • They are associated with an increased risk of persistent molar disease but are not associated with choriocarcinoma.

Complete moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes.
  • In about 90% of the cases, the genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46, XX karyotype.
  • In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms, resulting in a diploid karyotype, which is either 46, XX, or 46, XY.
  • In complete moles, the embryo usually dies early in the development, and hence, cannot be identified.

questions.text: A medical student is presenting a paper on retrosternal goitre. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms
Sternal incision is always required to operate
It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision

questions.solution:
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by neck incision (transcervical). 

Option A: Surgical removal of the retrosternal goitre is indicated in patients with significant airway compression, in young patients who have symptoms such as dyspnoea or dysphagia. 

Option B: Median sternotomy approach is indicated in:

  • Primary mediastinal goitre
  • Malignant retrosternal goitre
  • Very large retrosternal goitre
  • Recurrence in the mediastinum

For a primary mediastinal goitre whose boundaries are completely within the chest, resection is often achieved through median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplying the tumour are properly ligated. Removing the tumour through a cervical approach can result in uncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided. 

Option C: Blood supply to retrosternal goitre is from the thyroid vessels (secondary).

questions.text:
Which of the following are extra-esophageal complications associated with GERD?
  1. Asthma
  2. Laryngitis
  3. Pulmonary fibrosis
  4. Cough
questions.solution:
Asthma, laryngitis, pulmonary fibrosis, and cough are all extra esophageal complications in gastroesophageal reflux disease(GERD).
 
 Extraoesophageal symptoms of GERD are:

  • Chronic cough
  • Laryngitis,
  • Asthma
  • Dental erosions (especially on the lingual and palatal tooth
    surfaces).
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Sinusitis
  • Pharyngitis
  • Recurrent otitis media

Extraesophageal symptoms of GERD originate from the respiratory tract and include both laryngeal and pulmonary issues These symptoms can arise through two mechanisms. The first and most common mechanism involves proximal esophageal reflux and microaspiration of gastroduodenal contents, which cause direct injury to the larynx and lower respiratory tract. The second mechanism involves distal esophageal acid exposure triggering a vagal nerve reflex, leading to bronchospasm and cough, due to the shared vagal innervation of the trachea and esophagus.

The incidence of Barrett's esophagus is also more in patients with long term GERD, which in turn increases the risk of adenocarcinoma of esophagus.

questions.solution:

Vossius ring is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

It usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward and thus producing an impression of the iris on the lens. The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of Eale’s disease?
questions.solution:
Eale’s disease is an idiopathic inflammatory venous occlusion (phlebitis) that primarily affects the peripheral retina which is periphlebitis and is characterized by recurrent bilateral vitreous hemorrhage.

Eale's disease involves a chronic, idiopathic inflammatory process affecting the retinal veins. The inflammation leads to periphlebitis, which causes vessel wall damage and subsequent occlusion. The resulting retinal ischemia stimulates the release of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), promoting neovascularization. These new vessels are fragile and prone to bleeding, leading to vitreous hemorrhage. Persistent neovascularization can also cause fibrovascular proliferation, resulting in tractional forces that may lead to retinal detachment.

Fundoscopic examination reveals peri phlebitis, retinal hemorrhages, and areas of retinal ischemia. Fluorescein Angiography demonstrates retinal vasculitis, areas of non-perfusion, and neovascularization.

Management of Eale's disease includes prophylactic laser photocoagulation, anti-VEGF therapy, corticosteroids, and vitreoretinal surgery.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The type of speech that would be seen in this patient is?
questions.solution:
The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess. Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess or quinsy. 

Quinsy:

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

Clinical features: 

  • Sore throat/ Dysphagia 
  • Drooling of saliva 
  • Trismus 
  • Ipsilateral otalgia 
  • Fever 

Management of quinsy

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to combat dehydration
  • Antibiotics - Suitable antibiotics in large  i.v. doses to cover aerobes and anaerobes;
  • Analgesics like paracetamol are given for pain relief
  • Oral hygiene should be maintained by hydrogen peroxide or saline mouthwashes.
  • Drainage by needle aspiration, incision, and drainage or tonsillectomy.
  • Incision and drainage of the abscess: A peritonsillar abscess is opened at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

Other options:

Option A - Staccato voice or scanning speech is a broken speech seen in cerebellar lesions as well as multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in myasthenia gravis does not alter the disease process?
questions.solution:
Pyridostigmine is an anticholinesterase agent that does not alter the disease process of myasthenia gravis.

Anticholinesterase agents improve muscle contractions by allowing released acetylcholine to accumulate and act on the receptors over a large area and also have the additional direct depolarizing effect on the motor endplate.

But the underlying disease process continues and ultimately it may not be possible to restore muscle strength with anticholinesterase agents alone. It is due to the reduction of the receptors by the antibodies. It does not alter the disease process but provides symptomatic relief.

Drugs like prednisone, mycophenolate mofetil, and azathioprine are immunosuppressive agents that reduce the antibody titers and can modify the disease process (Options B, C, and D).

questions.text: A patient comes to the sleep clinic and the following pattern is seen on polysomnography. What type of breathing pattern is it?
questions.solution:
The breathing pattern shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes respiration. It is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing, followed by a gradual decrease that results in a temporary stop in breathing called apnea.

It is caused by an increased sensitivity of the respiratory center to arterial PCO2. There is an apneic phase, during which arterial PO2 falls and arterial PCO2 rises. These changes in the arterial blood gas content stimulate the respiratory center, resulting in hyperventilation and hypocapnia, followed by recurrence of apnea. It is present in 40% of patients with advanced HF and usually is associated with low cardiac output.

questions.text: A 75 year old woman with complaints of mass per vaginum, as shown in the below image was posted for operative repair. During the pre-anaesthetic check-up, she was found to be unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended for her?

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with progressive swelling of his right wrist associated with a dull aching pain. The orthopedician elicits tenderness on firm palpation of the swelling. The following findings are seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:

Osteoclastoma is a bone tumour with varying growth potential. It can be either benign/malignant, though it is more commonly benign. It is seen in patients who are 20-40 years of age. The commonly affected sites are the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the distal end of the radius.

Patients present with swelling and vague pain. Pathological fractures may also be seen. On examination, firm palpation can elicit tenderness. 

Radiologically, soap bubble appearance is seen due to interspersed lytic lesions and bone remnants. Intralesional curettage of the tumour is the common approach to management.

Option A: Chondrosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour arising from the cartilage cells. It may arise in any bone but is common in flat bones such as the scapula, pelvis, and ribs.

Option B: Osteosarcoma is a highly malignant primary bone tumor. Common sites are the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the upper end of the humerus. Patients present with a history of pain followed by swelling. Radiologically, periosteal reaction, sunburst appearance, and Codman's triangle can be seen. The characteristic sunburst appearance can be seen below.

Option D: Osteochondroma is a common benign tumour of the bone. The tumour stops enlarging in size once there is a cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate. questions.text:
Calculate the anion gap from the following values:
Na+ = 137 mmol/L
K+ = 4 mmol/L
Cl- = 100 mmol/L
HCO3- = 15 mmol/L
questions.solution:
The anion gap is 22 mmol/L.

The “anion gap” (which is only a diagnostic concept) is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:

Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ] − [HCO3− ] − [Cl− ]

Substituting the values = 137−15−100 = 22 mmol/L

The normal anion gap ranges between 8-16 mmol/L.

The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Therefore, there is no real “anion gap” in the plasma. 

However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl− and HCO3−.

Usually, the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations.

The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall:

  • Unmeasured cations - calcium, magnesium, and potassium
  • Unmeasured anions - albumin, phosphate, sulfate, and other organic anions

Decreased anion gap (<6 mEq/L) is seen in:

  • Increase in unmeasured cations
  • An addition of abnormal cations to the blood, such as:
    • Lithium (lithium intoxication)
    • Cationic immunoglobulins (plasma cell dyscrasias)
  • Reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration (nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or malabsorption)
  • Hyperviscosity and severe hyperlipidemia, can lead to an underestimation of sodium and chloride concentrations.

questions.text: The given pattern of EEG is found in:
questions.solution:
Periodic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes are seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

It is a spongiform encephalopathy that is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, akinetic mutism, cerebellar/visual disturbances. It is fatal and death usually within a year or less from the onset.

EEG shows characteristic periodic sharp wave complexes (bi/triphasic). CSF assay is positive for 14-3-3 protein.

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

  1. Sporadic (sCJD): Accounts for 85-90% of cases
    • MRI shows cortical ribbon sign
  2. Variant (vCJD): mad cow disease, Kuru
    • MRI shows hockey stick sign
  3. Familial (fCJD): 10% of cases (these individuals carry a PRPc mutation)
  4. Iatrogenic

Option A: Hepatic encephalopathy will show a triphasic wave pattern (negative-positive-negative wave). They are also seen in Hashimoto encephalopathy and CO2 narcosis.

Option C: GTCS (generalized tonic clonic seizures)will show high voltage bursts & high voltage spikes present in all the leads.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with aortic dissection. He continuously complains of hiccups. Which of the following nerves is most likely compressed in this case?
questions.solution:
Hiccups can be caused by irritation or stimulation of the phrenic nerve, which controls the diaphragm's movements. The structure marked as D is the phrenic nerve. 

The structures marked in the image are:

A. Right vagus nerve

B. Left vagus nerve

C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve

D. Right phrenic nerve

The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spine (C3-C5) and travels down through the chest to the diaphragm.

Aortic dissection occurs due to rupture in the inner layer of the aorta, and depending on the location of the tear, it can lead to a variety of symptoms, including pain, altered blood flow, and involvement of adjacent structures.

If the tear involves the ascending aorta or the arch of the aorta, it can potentially affect the adjacent structures, including the phrenic nerve. Irritation or compression of the phrenic nerve due to the dissection could lead to hiccups as a symptom.

questions.text: A male patient was brought by his mother concerned about his appearence. The image of the hands of a patient is given below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly).

The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly). 

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Features of Marfan's syndrome (Mnemonic: MARFAN’S)

  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Myopia due to upward dislocation of lens (bilateral ectopic lentis)
  • Aortic root dilatation, Aortic regurgitation
  • Retinal detachment
  • Fibrillin 1 gene defect: Reduced fibrillin 1 production causing joint laxity
  • Fifteen (Chromosome 15 is involved)
  • Flat feet
  • Arachnodactyly, Astigmatism, Air in lungs (Pneumothorax)
  • Nearsightedness
  • Subluxation of lens, Scoliosis, Speech disorders, Sleep apnea

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • ectopia lentis
  • myopia
  • flat cornea
  • retinal detachments
  • early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • thoracic scoliosis
  • spontaneous pneumothorax
  • striae atrophicae in the skin

Other options:

  • Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

questions.text: A middle aged female patient comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump is 9×10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of cystosarcoma phyllodes/Phyllodes tumor of the breast.

Phyllodes tumor, also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes, presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition.

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes or serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some having low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors, and malignant type- Mastectomy

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor.

 

Other options:

Option B: Giant fibroadenomas are usually seen in the early reproductive years. These are benign solid encapsulated tumors. It is a slow-growing tumor and presents as a painless lump in the breast.

Option C and D: Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory cancer is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics. Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Patients with inflammatory carcinoma usually have a history revealing the rapid onset of the disease with progression over weeks to 3 months.

The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without an underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema, edema, and warmth of the breast as a result of lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day two, he came back to the hospital with complaints of increasing abdominal pain and fever. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy leading to a bile leak. 

Bile duct injury

  • Usually is manifested in the postoperative period
  • Clinical features
    • Fever
    • Increasing abdominal pain
    • Jaundice
    • Bile leakage from an incision

Diagnosis

Imaging: Ultrasonography

  • To assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree 

Treatment strategy

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
    • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
    • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of the entire biliary anatomy
    • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)
    • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if a cystic-duct stump leak is suspected
  • Reestablishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

 Option A: Infection is very unlikely to present in the immediate postoperative period with a pus collection of 5x5cms particularly after laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Option B: Surgical site pain will not be severe and diffuse instead it is localized and bearable.

Option D: Retained gallstones are very unlikely.

questions.text: A patient presents with backache, night sweats, an evening increase in temperature, and unintentional weight loss. Laboratory tests reveal an increase in CRP and ESR levels. An MRI is provided below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given spine MRI shows a patient with Pott's spine. The image depicts sagittal T1W (A) and T2W (B) images in a patient with spinal tuberculosis showing a well-defined, round lesion (arrow) with T1 hypointensity and T2 iso-hypointensity.

  • Pott's disease, also known as tuberculous spondylitis, refers to the vertebral body and intervertebral disc involvement in tuberculosis (TB).
  • The spine is the most frequent location of musculoskeletal TB, and commonly related symptoms are back pain and lower limb weakness/paraplegia.
  • The spine is involved due to hematogenous spread via the venous plexus of Batson.
  • There is usually a slow collapse of one or usually more vertebral bodies, which spreads underneath the longitudinal ligaments.
  • This results in an acute kyphotic or "gibbus" deformity.
  • This angulation, coupled with epidural granulation tissue and bony fragments, can lead to cord compression.

Radiographic Features:

Features include irregularity of both the endplate and anterior aspect of the vertebral bodies, with bone marrow edema and enhancement seen on MRI:

  • T1: hypointense marrow in adjacent vertebrae
  • T2: hyperintense marrow, disc, soft tissue infection
  • T1 C+ (Gd): marrow, subligamentous, discal, dural enhancement

The paraspinal collections are typically well-circumscribed, with fluid centres and well-defined enhancing margins.

Other options: 

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis: shows Squaring and bridging of the vertebral body, leading to a bamboo spine appearance.

Option B: Multiple myeloma is the malignant production of plasma cells that results in bone pain or fractures, renal failure, increased susceptibility to infections, anemia, hypercalcemia, and manifestations of hyperviscosity. Radiography shows multiple well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions of various sizes scattered throughout the skull, giving the raindrop skull appearance.

Option C: Pyogenic spondylitis denotes infections impacting different components of the spine, including the vertebrae, intervertebral discs, paraspinal soft tissue, or epidural space. This umbrella term covers conditions such as vertebral osteomyelitis, spondylodiscitis, and epidural abscess.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man developed severe pain abdomen and fever 3 days after undergoing surgery for bowel perforation. There is no dehiscence or discharge from the sutured wound seen. His blood pressure was 60/40mmHg and his intra-abdominal pressure was 35mmHg. The procedure in the given image was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?

IAP- Intrabdominal pressure
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is abdominal compartment syndrome.

The above clinical features of increase in intraabdominal pressure >35 mmHg without any wound dehiscence, discharge and the given image showing rapid decompression of the abdomen by letting out the bowel and covering it with a plastic bag (Bogota bag) are suggestive of abdominal compartment syndrome.

Abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) is increased intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) leading to organ dysfunction. The normal IAP is 5-7 mmHg. When the IAP is > 12 mmHg, it is termed intra-abdominal hypertension. Abdominal compartment syndrome occurs when the IAP is > 20 mmHg as in this clinical scenario.

Physiological changes in ACS are:

  • Central nervous system- Increased intracranial pressure
  • Respiratory system- Decreased compliance, increased airway pressures, pulmonary artery pressure, and central venous pressure
  • Cardiovascular system- Decreased venous return, cardiac output, stroke volume, and increased systemic vascular resistance
  • Renal system- Decreased renal blood flow, glomerular filtration rate, and urine output

Grading of ACS:

  • Grade I: 10-15 mmHg
  • Grade II: 16-25 mmHg
  • Grade III: 26-35 mmHg
  • Grade IV: > 35 mmHg

Diagnosis is made by measuring IAP using a urinary bladder (Foley's catheter) or gastric catheter. CT scan, abdominal perfusion pressure, renal filtration gradient are some of the tests done to check organ dysfunction.

The primary goal of management is to reduce the IAP. So rapid decompression is done by opening the abdomen and performing a temporary closure of the abdominal wall using a mesh or a plastic bag (Bogota bag). After the resuscitation and management of the specific causes, a definite closure of the abdomen can be done by vacuum-assisted closure (VAC), split-skin graft, or prosthetic mesh.

Other options:

Option B- Meleney's synergistic gangrene of the abdominal wall is the post-operative infection due to microaerophilic streptococci, staphylococci and other anaerobes. It is characterized by sudden pain, redness, blackening, and gangrene of the skin with abdominal wall necrosis. It is most commonly seen in HIV, diabetes, and immunocompromised people. Treatment includes antibiotics like penicillins and metronidazole, excision of the gangrenous tissue till it bleeds, skin grafting and management of toxaemia, hyperbaric oxygen, and critical care.

Option C- Burst abdomen is the mechanical wound failure causing separation of the closed abdominal wound associated with abdominal content evisceration. It usually occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days. A sudden giving way feeling from the wound precipitated by bouts of cough, pinkish serosanguinous discharge can be seen. Omentum or coils of the intestine are forced out of the wound. Management includes delayed closure with initial mesh wrap or Bogota bag, placing a subcutaneous drain, suitable antibiotic therapy, and prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome as described above.

Below is an image showing a burst abdomen.

Option D- Divarication of recti is the thinning of the linea alba in the epigastrium with protrusion of the abdominal wall with prominent edges of both recti. It becomes prominent on lifting the head from the bed. No treatment is required in the divarication of recti.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most dependent part of a female?
questions.solution:
The rectouterine pouch, which is also called the pouch of Douglas is the most dependent part of a female.

Peritoneum of the female pelvis:

In females, the peritoneum covers the anterior and anterolateral surfaces of the rectum, uterus, and urinary bladder. Spaces found in the female pelvis are:

Pararectal fossae: Present on either side of the rectum. They are limited laterally by the peritoneum that covers the uterosacral ligaments. 

Paravesical fossae: Present on either side of the bladder. It is limited laterally by the peritoneum which covers the round ligament of the uterus.

Rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas): The peritoneum which covers the anterior surface of the rectum is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterior surface of the posterior fornix of the vagina and the uterus, forming a rectouterine pouch.

Vesicouterine pouch: The peritoneum covering the fundus and body of the uterus, is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder forming a vesicouterine pouch.

Ovarian fossa: It is a shallow depression in the peritoneal lining of the lateral pelvic wall between the peritoneal ridges. It is formed by the obliterated umbilical arteries anteriorly, the ureter posteriorly, and the external iliac vessels above. It lies behind the lateral attachment of the broad ligament and contains the ovary in nulliparous females.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Central bronchiectasis( NOT distal bronchiectasis) is a typical feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

ABPA is an eosinophilic pulmonary disorder caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonisation of airways by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma (~2.5% of patients) or cystic fibrosis (up to 15%). In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction can lead to bronchiectasis, fibrosis and respiratory compromise.

With the development of ABPA, asthma or CF typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts.

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:

  • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml.
  • Positive skin prick test or IgE levels against A.fumigatus extract.
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies.
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL.

questions.text: Thirty minutes after a blood transfusion is started, the patient develops chills and severe flank pain. Temperature is 102.4 F and she begins bleeding around her IV catheter site. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:

This patient presents with high-grade fever (102.4 F and chills), flank pain and features suggestive of DIC (bleeding around her IV catheter site), 30 minutes after transfusion was started. The time course and presentation is consistent with acute hemolytic reaction. The first step is to stop transfusion immediately and then collect blood samples for testing.

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR)

  • fever, flank pain, hemoglobinuria, renal failure, and DIC
  • caused by ABO incompatibility, Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction
  • positive Direct Coomb's test, pink plasma
  • transfusion to be stopped immediately

  • Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) - Within 24 hours of transfusion
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR) - Within 6 hours of transfusion
  • Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) - After 24 hours of transfusion

questions.text: A woman presents with complaints of greenish-frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month. On examination vulvovaginal erythema is noticed. On saline microscopy, motile organisms are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and microscopic findings are suggestive of trichomoniasis.

The clinical features include vaginal discharge which is profuse, thin, slightly green in color, and frothy. It may be associated with vaginal irritation, dysuria, and increased frequency. Cervical inflammation with punctate hemorrhagic spots known as the strawberry cervix is typically seen in trichomoniasis, caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Motile trichomonads are seen on wet mount examination.

The below image shows the strawberry cervix seen in trichomoniasis.

Other options:

Option B: Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an alteration in the normal vaginal flora and presents a malodorous grey-white discharge. It is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria, where at least three of the four following criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine-like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

Option C: Chlamydial cervicitis may present with severe abdominal pain with high fever, dyspareunia, prolonged menstrual cycles, and intermenstrual bleeding can be elicited. On examination, cervicitis with a yellow, cloudy, mucoid discharge can be seen from the os. The cervix tends to bleed easily when scraped. 

Option D: Candidiasis is caused by infection with Candida albicans and presents with pruritus, burning, and dysuria with vulvar erythema, edema, and excoriations. A curdy white discharge will be present.

questions.text: A 18 year old male presented to the emergency department (ED) after a head-on collision with a vehicle traveling at 30 miles per hours (mph) while riding his bicycle. Patient initially presented with a Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) of 13, however, this rapidly deteriorated to a GCS of 5 within a four-hour window.  The doctor performed the CT scan and the image is given below. All of the following are indications for surgical evacuation EXCEPT ________ .
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with acute epidural hematoma. Axial CT shows a hyperdense lentiform (biconvex) opacity consistent with an epidural hematoma. The patient would need surgical evacuation if the hematoma is more than 30 mL.

Extradural hematoma (EDH) / Epidural hematoma:

  • It is a collection of blood that forms between the inner surface of the skull and the outer layer of the dura, which is called the periosteal layer.
  • It is commonly associated with a history of trauma and associated skull fracture.
  • The source of bleeding- A torn meningeal artery (most commonly, the middle meningeal artery).
  • It is associated with an underlying fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone.
  • The patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a “lucid interval,” while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.
  • Investigations- CT and MRI.
  • It can cause a mass effect with herniation. 
  • Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.
  • They are usually limited by cranial sutures, but not by venous sinuses.

CT Changes :

  1. Typical hyperdense lentiform (biconvex) opacity with mass effect.
  2. Swirl sign:
    • It refers to the non-contrast CT appearance of acute extravasation of blood into a hematoma, for example, an extradural hematoma or subdural hematoma.
    • It represents unclotted fresh blood which is of lower attenuation than clotted blood that surrounds it.

The definitive management is craniotomy with emergency evacuation of the hematoma.

Surgical evacuation of the hematoma is required if:

  • the volume of hematoma is more than 30 mL
  • the thickness of the hematoma is >1.5 cm
  • midline shift is > 5mm
  • GCS is <8.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman was admitted by her parents due to inappropriate behaviour for the past 7 months. In the OPD, she constantly wandered, pointed aimlessly at her surroundings, burst into laughter without any reason, and made lip-sucking actions. She said that an evil giant was always around her although no one was near her. Lack of personal care and unorganized behaviour was also noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of schizophrenia, which is likely to be of the hebephrenic or disorganized type.

Hebephrenic schizophrenia (disorganized) has early onset, generally occurring before 25 years of age. It is characterized by marked regression of behaviour that becomes disorganized and poor contact with reality. Social behaviour and emotional responses are inappropriate. It has the worst prognosis after simple schizophrenia. 

Schizophrenia is a psychotic disorder with the following criteria: 

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms), where 2 or more of the following have to be present (at least one must be among the a, b, or c): 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behavior
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

3. The rest of the 6-month period may include

  • Continuing psychotic symptoms
  • Prodromal symptoms preceding clear-cut psychosis
  • Residual symptoms after the resolution of the psychotic symptoms

4. Residual symptoms are defined as attenuated forms of psychotic symptoms, such as

  • Odd beliefs
  • Magical thinking
  • Ideas of reference
  • Odd perceptual experiences
  • Peculiar or concrete thinking
  • Vague speech
  • Odd behavior
  • Negative symptoms may also be included

5. Exclusion of mood disorder & substance abuse

Other types of schizophrenia

Paranoid schizophrenia:

  • Most common type.
  • Often called paraphrenia in progressive deterioration. 
  • Usual onset in 3rddecade
  • Characterized by delusions of persecution, grandeur, control, etc.
  • Can be associated with hallucination

Catatonic schizophrenia:

  • Marked disturbance in motor function
  • May involve stupor, negativism, rigidity, excitement, or posturing
  • Alteration between extremes of excitement and stupor
  • Best prognosis
  • Term coined by Kahlbaum

Simple schizophrenia:

  • The primary symptom is withdrawal from social and work-related situations
  • Characterized by a gradual, insidious loss of drive and ambition
  • Do not experience persistent hallucinations or delusions
  • Poor prognosis (simple > hebephrenic)

The cardiotocograph shows sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern and is not seen in fetal head compression which shows early deceleration. Sinusoidal pattern is seen in the following conditions.

questions.text: A male child presented to the emergency department complaining of pain and swelling over scrotum which began 2 days back. It was noticed that the child is febrile. On examination, the testes were normally placed and on elevating the testes, pain was not reduced. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in management is Doppler ultrasonography. A child presenting with scrotal pain, swelling and fever is likely acute epididymo-orchitis. If the diagnosis of epididymo-orchitis is uncertain, doppler ultrasonography would be useful revealing increased blood flow to affected epidiymis. 

On elevation of testes, if the pain gets relieved, it is likely to be epididymo-orchitis and if it gets aggravated  it is probably torsion testis, which is known as the Prehn’s sign. If prehn’s sign is equivocal, doppler ultrasonography has to be done to confirm the blood supply. 

Epididymo-orchitis presents as gradual onset pain over the scrotum, with increased frequency of micturition or burning sensation while passing urine. The most important predisposing factor is urinary tract infections. On examination, we find that the testes is normally placed and cremasteric reflex is present 

Treatment of epididymo-orchitis includes scrotal support, anti-inflammatory drugs and antibiotics.

The important differential diagnosis is Testicular torsion. In case of torsion, lifting the involved testis increases the pain. Also testis usually lies at a higher level. Cremastric reflex would be absent. Urgent surgical exploration is to be done in case of torsion.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt trauma to the abdomen. He is diagnosed to have a retroperitoneal injury with a pulsatile hematoma in the zone highlighted in the image below. Which of the following is true about the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The area highlighted in the image represents Zone 2 of the retroperitoneum and an injury here with a pulsatile hematoma should be treated surgically.

The retroperitoneum is divided into 3 zones, based on the types of viscera and their differential management in blunt trauma.

Zone 1 Central Always explored, after proximo-distal vascular control
Zone 2 Lateral Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization
Zone 3 Pelvic Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization

If there is a penetrative injury in any of the zones, surgical management is done. Pelvic hematomas are difficult to control. Compression and intraperitoneal packing are preferred whenever possible.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of intense itching, photophobia, and ropy discharge from his eyes. Moreover, on examination the following finding is present. What is the most probable diagnosis of this patient?

VKC is bilateral allergic conjunctivitis that is common in children above the age of 5 years and in warm dry climates such as the Mediterranean, sub-Saharan Africa, and the Middle East.

It is IgE and cell-mediated inflammation of the conjunctiva. It results in the following findings:

Palpebral disease

  • Cobblestone papillae: Macropapillae (<1 mm) have a flat-topped polygonal appearance reminiscent of cobblestones
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell–Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal disease

  • Horner-Trantas dots which are limbal conjunctival papillae

Keratopathy

  • Superior punctate epithelial erosions
  • Shield ulcers, which may develop when the exposed Bowman membrane becomes coated with mucus and calcium phosphate, leading to inadequate wetting and delayed re-epithelialization.
  • Pseudogerentexon resembling arcus senilus. It has a cupid's bow outline

Treatment of VKC includes allergen avoidance, antihistaminics, steroids, and immunomodulators both topical and systemic depending on the severity of the disease.

questions.text: An infant with hydrocephalus is found to have pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly. On further investigations, he is also found to have hearing loss and rugger-jersey spine on radiography. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the infantile form of osteopetrosis. It is characterised by decreased osteoclastic activity due to defect in carbonic anhydrase ll proton pump.

The excessive new bone formation with defective resorption leads to abnormal development of the skull, especially causing narrowing of the foramina of the skull. This leads to various complications like hydrocephalus, cranial nerve compression leading to deafness and facial palsy, sinus blockage, etc. Excess bone density also leads to rugger jersey appearance of vertebrae on radiography.

Failure of bone resorption results in poorly formed medullary cavity. This leads to defective hematopoiesis in the medullary cavity and stimulation of extramedullary hematopoiesis. Hence, the infant presents with pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly.

Abnormal bone density may also lead to altered vasculature causing complications like osteitis of the mandible.

Note: Renal failure leads to osteodystrophy leading to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Rugger jersey spine is also suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with nausea, vomiting, and acute onset epigastric pain radiating to the back. Investigations revealed elevated levels of serum amylase and lipase. An abdominal X-ray showed the colon-cut off sign.  Which of the following criteria uses CT to stage the severity of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the abdominal radiograph showing the colon cut-off sign are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Balthazar Scoring is used for staging the severity of acute pancreatitis based on CT findings.

The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are - gallstones, alcoholism, post-ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography), drugs (steroids, thiazides, azathioprine, etc.), hypercalcemia, etc. 

The classical presentation includes acute severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and relieved by leaning forward. Nausea and vomiting can also be present. Clinical signs such as hypotension, tachycardia, Grey Turner sign (bluish discoloration of the flanks), and Cullen’s sign (bluish discoloration around the umbilicus) can be present.

The Grey Turner sign is shown below:

Cullen's sign is shown below:

The below abdominal x-ray shows an abrupt transition from distended to collapsed colon just beyond the splenic flexure. This is known as a colon cut-off sign.

Laboratory findings include elevated serum amylase and serum lipase. Serum amylase levels are non-specific, while serum lipase is more specific, and lipase is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours from the onset of symptoms.

Management involves keeping the patient nil per oral, fluid replacement, and pain control. Antibiotics are rarely required unless the infection spreads.

Other options-

Option A: Modified Glasgow score uses 8 laboratory findings to predict the severity of acute pancreatitis (within 48 hours of treatment onset). It is not a CT-based scoring system.

Option C: APACHE II score (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation score) is another clinical tool that assesses the risk of mortality and predicts prolonged intensive care treatment. It is also not CT-based.

Option D: Ranson's criteria uses 11 clinical and laboratory findings at admission and after 48 hours to assess clinical severity. It does not include CT scan findings.

questions.solution:
The above image shows reverse trendelenberg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet.  It is named so, as the position is reverse of the trendelenberg position, where the head end is lower and the feet is at higher level.

Example: In laparoscopic cholecystectomy the patient is placed in a reverse trendelenburg position slightly rotated to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder which is retracted towards the diaphragm.

The trendelenberg and reverse trendelenberg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and side boards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

 

Option A: Lloyd Davis position - head down lithotomy used in pelvic and rectal surgeries. (image below)

Option B: Jack knife position - prone with buttocks elevated (also known as Kraske position) used in colorectal surgeries. (image below)

Option C: Trendelenberg position - head down position used in hernia surgeries, surgeries of abdomen and genitourinary system, placement of central venous catheter in the interal jugular vein or the subclavian vein. (image below)

  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side.

  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with persistent fever and productive cough for 6 weeks with night sweats and anemia. The following is his CXR. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described along with the chest X-ray image showing air-fluid level is suggestive of a lung abscess.

The patients usually present with complaints of fever, cough with sputum production, and chest pain. Patients with putrid lung abscesses may report foul-smelling sputum. Patients with chronic lung abscesses usually have a history of night sweats, fatigue, and anemia.

On physical examination:

  • Poor dentition/gingival disease
  • Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds on lung auscultation
  • Digital clubbing
  • The absence of a gag reflex

CXR features of lung abscess:

  • A lung cavity with an air-fluid level
  • The cavity wall is thick and irregular, and a surrounding pulmonary-infiltrate is often present
  • Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities

The two x-ray images given below show thick-walled cavities with air-fluid levels on lateral and PA views respectively.

Other options:

Carcinoma Lung:

  • Carcinoma of the lung can also present with symptoms like persistent cough, fever, night sweats, and anemia, especially if it has advanced and caused complications like infection or bleeding.
  • However, the CXR would show a different pattern such as a solitary pulmonary nodule, mass lesion, or hilar enlargement.
  • It may also demonstrate signs of metastasis such as multiple nodules in the lungs or distant spread to other organs, which are not apparent in the provided CXR.

Emphysematous bullae:

  • Emphysematous bullae are large air spaces within the lung parenchyma that can occur due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or other lung conditions.
  • While emphysema can lead to symptoms like cough and occasionally fever if there's a concurrent infection, it typically does not present with prolonged fever, night sweats, and anemia as prominent features. Additionally, the CXR shows consolidation rather than bullae.

Tuberculosis (TB):

  • TB is less likely in this scenario due to the presence of clinical features such as foul-smelling sputum, digital clubbing, and the absence of a gag reflex, which are not typical of TB.
  • Additionally, the CXR findings of a thick-walled cavity with an air-fluid level are more suggestive of a lung abscess.

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pressure sore with extensive tissue destruction, including damage to the muscle layer and thus it belongs to stage 4.

Pressure sores also referred known as bed sores, pressure ulcers and decubitus ulcers are ulcers that occur due to prolonged pressure on certain sites thereby leading to tissue necrosis. The commonest sites involved are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral >medial), and occiput. Paraplegic patients, elderly patients, and severely ill patients are at a higher risk of developing pressure sores.

They are staged as:

  • Stage 1 - Erythema with no blanching and no breach in the epidermis.
  • Stage 2- Partial-thickness skin loss with epidermal and dermal involvement.
  • Stage 3- Full-thickness skin loss with intact fascia but the involvement of the subcutaneous tissue.
  • Stage 4- Full-thickness skin loss extending to the fascia with massive tissue destruction and involvement of muscle, bone, tendon, or joint. 

Management is primarily proper skin care with pressure dispersion cushions, air-fluidized beds, and urinary or fecal diversion if required. Patients who are bed-bound should be turned once in 2 hours. Those in a wheelchair should lift themselves off the seat for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

Surgery is the last resort and is done after a proper initial debridement and vacuum-assisted closure. Vacuum-assisted closure is a wound closure technique in which negative pressure is applied to the wound which leads to a decrease in edema. This hastens the debridement and formation of granulation tissue. Skin flaps with a muscle are also used for closure.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man working in the ship repair industry presents with a gradually progressive cough and difficulty breathing. The flow-volume curve after spirometry in the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

Pink line - Patient's response
Green dashed lines - Normal response
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 48-year-old patient working in a ship repair industry with a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve is asbestosis. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

The flow-volume curve of the above (patient 1) shows decreased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right. This is seen in restrictive lung disease. Airflow is greater than normal at comparable lung volumes because the increased elastic recoil of the lungs holds the airways open.

Asthma, COPD, emphysema, and endobronchial neoplasm present with obstructive flow patterns. Although all airflow is diminished, expiratory prolongation predominates, and mean expiratory flow < mean inspiratory flow. The increased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume will shift the flow volume loop to left.

Vocal cord paralysis causes a variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction in which only the inspiratory curve would be flattened.

 

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung directly related to the intensity and duration of exposure. 

Asbestos fibers induce oxidative injury due to the generation of reactive oxygen species by the transition metals on the surface of the fibers as well as from cells engaged in phagocytosis. These mechanisms result in lung fibrosis.

Irregular or linear opacities initially in the lower lung fields are the hallmark of asbestosis in chest radiographs. A gound glass appearance in the lung fields may be seen.

The chest X-ray below shows bilateral calcified pleural plaques consistent with asbestos-related pleural disease:

 

No specific therapy is available for asbestosis. They are managed with supportive therapy. The most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure is lung cancer. Pleural and peritoneal mesothelioma are also associated with asbestos exposure. 

Other options:

Options A and B: Emphysema and asthma are obstructive lung disorders. In these conditions, the flow-volume loop would be a scooped-out curve.

Option D: Vocal cord paralysis causes variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction. The flow-volume loop would have a flat inspiratory curve.

questions.solution:

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions would you expect a t(8;14) translocation?
questions.solution:
Burkitt's lymphoma is associated with the following chromosomal abnormalities:

  • t(8;14) or MYC-IGH - 75-85% of cases
  • t(8;22 )
  • t(2;8)

Burkitt lymphoma, also known as small non-cleaved-cell lymphoma, is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is the most common NHL in children <15 years.  It is characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-myc gene on chromosome 8. The translocation most commonly seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14).

It can occur in 3 forms mainly presenting in children or young adults

  • African (endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it often presents as a mass involving the mandible. It may also involve the abdominal viscera, particularly the kidneys, ovaries, and adrenal glands. 
  • Sporadic (non-endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it most often appears as a mass involving the ileocecum and peritoneum
  • Aggressive lymphoma or acute leukaemia - it is seen in immunocompromised individuals

Histopathology

Tumour cells show multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm and a high mitotic index. They are closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky).

The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm of these phagocytes washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris (the stars).

Treatment is by Radiotherapy and Chemotherapy(Cyclophosphamide, methotrexate and orthomelphalan). Surgery is usually not indicated unless it is localised or in case of involvement of ovaries. The prognosis is good.
