    • Prophylactic therapy to the CNS is mandatory
  • Cure rate is 70-80% (good prognosis)

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency department with swelling and pain over the proximal forearm. The mother claims that the child fell on an outstretched hand while playing with friends. The radiograph shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The plain radiograph shows a fracture of the proximal ulna along with a dislocation of the head of the radius. This type of injury is termed a Monteggia fracture.

Patients present with symptoms such as swelling and pain in the proximal forearm region. The mechanism of injury in such a fracture is usually a fall on an outstretched hand or a direct injury to the back of the upper forearm.

Monteggia fracture is an unstable fracture and is usually managed surgically with open reduction and internal fixation.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of the ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic alcoholic has a distended abdomen, behavioural changes, yellowish discoloration of the skin, and decreased urine output. His laboratory investigations show elevated liver enzymes and creatinine. USG shows normal kidneys. What is the definitive treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point to a diagnosis of hepatorenal syndrome and the definitve treatment of the same is liver transplantation. 
 
Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) is a form of functional renal failure without any renal pathology that occurs in some patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure. The pathophysiological hallmark is severe renal vasoconstriction.
 
There are two types of HRS:
  • Type 1 HRS: There is progressive impairment in renal function and a marked decline in creatinine clearance within 1–2 weeks of presentation.
  • Type 2 HRS: There is a drop in glomerular filtration rate with elevated creatinine levels. It has a better prognosis than type 1 HRS.

Ultrasound of the kidney shows normal study and hyaline casts may be observed, indicating prerenal failure.

Management:

  • Stop diuretics
  • Albumin infusion at 1g/kg/day
  • Medical management:
    • Vasopressin analogs- terlipressin
    • Somatostatin analogs- octreotide
    • Alpha-adrenergic agonists- midodrine, noradrenaline
  • Definitive treatment: Liver transplantation

questions.text: A mother brings her son to the OPD after noticing a convergent squint. Leukocoria is noted on examination. Enucleation is done and histological analysis of the specimen revealed Flexner- Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above mentioned features of leukocoria and strabismus along with the presence of Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes are suggestive of a diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood. It is associated with germline RB1 mutations. 

The most common presentations are leukocoria (white pupillary reflex/amaurotic cat's eye appearance) and strabismus. Fundus examination is therefore mandatory in all cases of childhood squint.

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a characteristic histological feature seen in retinoblastoma. Chemotherapy and enucleation are done depending on the extent of tumor involvement.

Other options

Option B: Congenital toxoplasmosis is associated with bilateral and multiple chorioretinal lesions in the fundus, also involving the macular area.

Option C: Retinopathy of prematurity is a retinal vascular disease seen in premature infants and characterized by defective retinal vascularisation.

Option D: Coats disease is idiopathic retinal telangiectasia characterized by unilateral visual loss, strabismus, and leukocoria. There are no characteristic histological findings in this disease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient came to the hospital for medical termination of pregnancy. From whom will you obtain consent for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Only the patient's consent is required for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) and her male partner's consent is not required.

Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 yrs or if the patient is mentally ill.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman with a previous history of preterm delivery presents at 32 weeks with intermittent uterine contractions. To allow for fetal lung maturity, what is the dose of betamethasone to be given?
questions.solution:
To allow for fetal lung maturity, the dose of betamethasone to be given is 12mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses.

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome(RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage(IVH), and necrotizing enterocolitis(NEC). 

Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Short-term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). The drugs include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labor, and placental abruption.

Preterm labour is the onset of labour before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies and genital tract infection. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labour to look for cervical incompetence. 

Features of preterm labour include regular uterine contractions at least once every 10 minutes, with/without pain, cervical dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% and length of cervix <2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm.

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is diagnosed with non pressure hydrocephalus. An MRI brain demonstrates ventricular enlargement. After a serial lumbar puncture, his gait significantly improves. Which of the following is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is normal-pressure hydrocephalus, and MRI is showing enlarged ventricles. Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting is preferred in this condition.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a reversible cause of dementia. It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.

Clinical features of NPH triad:

  • ataxia (magnetic gait is described as slow and unsteady turns that are slow, broad-based, and short-stepped)
  • dementia
  • urinary incontinence

Papilloedema is not seen.

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting- It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options: 

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension presents with transient vision loss, headache, and papilledema. Medical therapy includes acetazolamide and furosemide. Topiramate is also used due to carbonic anhydrase inhibitor activity. Surgical therapy includes optic nerve sheath decompression (or optic nerve sheath fenestration) and CSF shunting procedures.
